and is only beginning to turn to the critical examination of its future, emphasis
on its cultural progress, and the development of harmony among its diverse popula¬
tion.
San Bernardino is one of the eleven cities participating in the Test Cities
Project of the Fund for Adult Education. San Bernardino Valley College (a public,
tax-supported junior college) cooperates with the Fund in this project and has
created the Community Education Project as the administrative arm of the College to
carry on this ■vrork. The Community Education Project had the responsibility for the
WAYS OF MANKIND Experiment.
MATERIALS USED IN THE WAYS OF MANKIND EXPERIMENT
The experiment was built around a radio series bearing the common name of
Ways of Mankind. The series consisted of thirteen programs, each of a half hour’s
duration, developed by the National Association of Educational Broadcasters, under
a grant from the Fund for Adult Education. Dr. Walter Goldschmidt, anthropologist.
University of California at Los Angeles, had over-all responsibility for developing
the radio series. Nine of these programs were chosen for the Experiment.
The series constituted an introduction to basic anthropology. Educational in
nature, the programs also represented American radio at its best. They were skil¬
fully done, highly dramatic, interest-sustaining, and executed m th humor and the
